chapter.title: Deploying the &ostack; Services
chapter.para: Once the nodes are installed and configured you can start deploying the &ostack; services in order to finalize the installation. The services need to be deployed in a given order, because they depend on one another. Deployment is done from the &crow; Web interface through recipes, so-called &barcl;s.

The services controlling the cloud (including storage management and control services) need to be installed on the &contrnode;(s). However, you may not use your &contrnode;(s) as a compute node or storage host for &o_objstore; or &ceph;. Here is a list with services that may not be installed on the &contrnode;(s): Swift-storage, &ceph;-store, Nova-multi-compute. These services need to be installed on dedicated nodes.

The &ostack; services need to be deployed in the following order. For general instructions on how to edit and deploy &barcl;, refer to . Deploying &swift; and &ceph; is optional; all other services must be deployed.

sect1.title: &barcl;s
sect1.para: The &ostack; services are automatically installed on the nodes by using so-called &barcl;s—a set of recipes, templates, and installation instructions. All existing &barcl;s can be accessed from the &crow; Web interface by clicking on Barclamps. To edit a &barcl;, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open a browser and point it to the &crow; Web interface available at port 3000 of the &admserv;, for example . Log in as user crowbar. The password defaults to crowbar, if you have not changed it.

Click Barclamps to open the All Barclamps menu. Alternatively you may filter the list to Crowbar or &ostack; &barcl;s by choosing the respective option from Barclamps. The Crowbar &barcl;s contain general recipes for setting up and configuring all nodes, while the &ostack; are dedicated to &ostack; service deployment and configuration.
You can either Create a proposal or Edit an existing one.
Most &ostack; &barcl;s consist of two sections: the Attributes section lets you change the configuration, and the Node Deployment section lets you choose onto which nodes to deploy the &barcl;.
To edit the Attributes section, change the values via the Web form. Alternatively you can directly edit the configuration file by clicking Raw.

warning.title: Raw Mode
warning.para: Only use the Raw mode in case an option cannot be changed via Web form. Raw mode does not perform any syntax checks.
If you switch between Raw mode and Web form (Custom mode), make sure to Save your changes before switching, otherwise they will be lost.

step.para: In the Node Deployment section of the &ostack; &barcl; you can drag and drop nodes from the Available Nodes column to the desired role. You need to drop the node onto the role name. Do not drop a node onto the input field—this is rather used to filter the list of Available Nodes!

One or more nodes are usually automatically pre-selected for available roles. If this pre-selection does not meet your requirements, remove it before dragging new nodes to the role. To remove a node from a role, click the respective Remove icon.

To save and deploy your edits, click Apply. To just save your changes without deploying them, click Save. To remove the complete proposal, click Delete. A proposal that already has been deployed can only be deleted manually, see for details.
If you deploy a proposal onto a node where a previous one is still active, the new proposal will overwrite the old one.

note.title: Wait Until a Proposal has been Deployed
note.para: Deploying a proposal might take some time (up to several minutes). It is strongly recommended to always wait until you see the note Successfully applied the proposal before proceeding on to the next proposal.

warning.title: &barcl; Deployment Failure
warning.para: In case the deployment of a &barcl; fails, make sure to fix the reason that has caused the failure and deploy the &barcl; again. Refer to the respective troubleshooting section at for help. A deployment failure may leave your node in an inconsistent state.

sect2.title: Delete a Proposal that Already has been Deployed
sect2.para: To delete a proposal that already has been deployed, you first need to Deactivate it in the &crow; Web interface. Deactivating a proposal will remove software and services having been deployed by this proposal from the affected nodes. After a proposal has been deactivated, you can Delete it in the &crow; Web interface and Create a new proposal from the &barcl; overview.

sect1.title: Deploying the Database
sect1.para: The very first service that needs to be deployed is the Database. The database service using PostgreSQL is used by all other services. It must be installed on a &contrnode;.
The only attribute you may change is the maximum number of database connections (Global Connection Limit ). The default value should work in most cases.

sect1.title: Deploying &o_ident;
sect1.para: &o_ident; is another core component that is used by all other &ostack; services. It provides authentication and authorization services. &o_ident; needs to be installed on a &contrnode;. You can configure the following parameters of this &barcl;:

listitem.para: Set the algorithm used by &o_ident; to generate the tokens. It's strongly recommended to use PKI, since it will reduce network traffic.
Tenant for the users. Do not change the default value of openstack.
Username and password for the regular user and the administrator. Both accounts can be used to log in to the &cloud; ‐ to manage &o_ident; users and access.

When sticking with the default value HTTP, public communication will not be encrypted . Choose HTTPS to use SSL for encryption. See for background information and for installation instructions. The following additional configuration options will become available when choosing HTTPS:

varlistentry.term: SSL Certificate File / SSL (Private) Key File

listitem.para: Location of the certificate key pair files.

Check this option if using self-signed certificates in order to disable certificate checks. You should only self-signed certificates for non-production deployments. Always use properly signed certificates in production environments. Never check this option in a production deployment!

varlistentry.term: Require Client Certificate / SSL CA Certificates File

listitem.para: If your certificates are signed by a trusted third party organization, Require Client Certificate should be set to false, since the official certification authorities (CA) are already known by the system. If the certificates are signed by a CA within your organization or by any other CA not known by the system, a CA certificate is needed.

sect1.title: Deploying RabbitMQ
sect1.para: The RabbitMQ messaging system enables services to communicate with the other nodes via Advanced Message Queue Protocol (AMQP). Deploying it is mandatory. RabbitMQ needs to be installed on a &contrnode;. It is recommended not to change the default values of the proposal's attributes.

sect1.title: Deploying &swift; (optional)
sect1.para: &swift; adds an object storage service to &cloud; that lets you store single files such as images or snapshots. It offers high data security by storing the data redundantly on a pool of &stornode;s—therefore &swift; needs to be installed on at least two dedicated nodes.

It is recommended not to change the defaults in the &barcl; proposal, unless you know exactly what you require. However you should change the Cluster Admin Password. If you plan to change the Zone value, it is important to know that you need at least as many &stornode;s as Zones.
The &swift; service consists of four different roles:

listitem.para: The ring maintains the information about the location of objects, replicas, and devices. It can be compared to an index, that is used by various &ostack; services to look up the physical location of objects. Swift-ring-compute must only be installed on a single node; it is recommended to use a &contrnode;.
The &swift; proxy server takes care of routing requests to &swift;. Installing a single instance of Swift-proxy on a &contrnode; is recommended.
The &swift; dispersion tools are needed to measure the health of the cluster. Swift-dispersion needs to be installed on the same node as Swift-proxy, installing both on a &contrnode; is recommended.
The virtual object storage service. Install this role on all dedicated &swift; &stornode;s (at least two), but not on any other node.

warning.title: Swift-storage Needs Dedicated Machines
warning.para: Never install the Swift-storage service on a node that runs other &ostack; services.

chapter.sect1:
Deploying &ceph; (optional, unsupported)
&ceph; adds a redundant block storage service to &cloud;. It lets you store persistent devices that can be mounted from &vmguest;s. It offers high data security by storing the data redundantly on a pool of &stornode;s—therefore &ceph; needs to be installed on at least two dedicated nodes.
For more information on the &ceph; project, vist .
&no-ceph-support;
The &ceph; &barcl; only has one configuration option: telling &ceph; which devices to use on the nodes. Enter a comma-separated list of devices that should be used by &ceph;. For example:
"dev/sdb, /dev/sdc, /dev/sdd
Devices
Not all of the devices used for &ceph; need to exist on all nodes. All devices from a node matching the list will be used. They must not be mounted prior to deploying &ceph;. Any data stored on these devices will be lost.
The &ceph; service consists of three different roles:
Ceph-mon-master
Master cluster monitor daemon for the &ceph; distributed file system. Ceph-mon-master must only be installed on a single node; it is recommended to use a &contrnode; (FIXME is this true?).
Ceph-mon
Cluster monitor daemon for the &ceph; distributed file system. Ceph-mon needs to be installed on two or four &stornode;s.
Number of &ceph; Monitor Nodes
In addition to the node running the &ceph;-mon-master service an additional two or four nodes also need to run the &ceph;-mon service. The sum of the &ceph;-mon-master and the &ceph;-mon nodes must always be an odd number (either three or five).
Nodes running Ceph-mon cannot be deleted or temporarily be disabled.
Ceph-store
The virtual block storage service. Install this role on all dedicated &ceph; &stornode;s (at least two), but not on any other node.
Ceph-store Needs Dedicated Machines
Never deploy Ceph-store on a node that runs other non-&ceph; &ostack; services. The only service that may be deployed together with it is Ceph-mon.
Deploying &ceph; requires to perform the steps in a given order:
Edit the &barcl; proposal to specify the devices to be used by &ceph; as described above.
Drag and drop a node (for example, a &contrnode;) to the &ceph;-mon-master role.
Drag and drop two or four nodes to the &ceph;-mon role. Note that the maximum number of &ceph;-mon nodes cannot exceed four and that the sum of &ceph;-mon-master and &ceph;-mon nodes must be odd.
Drag and drop all dedicated &ceph; &stornode;s to the &ceph;-store (at least two). You may also use the nodes with the &ceph;-mon roles, but not the &ceph;-mon-master node (you can add that one later).
Click Apply to deploy your proposal. This can take some time.
If you also want to use the &ceph;-mon-master as a &stornode;, drag and drop it to the &ceph;-store role and click Apply again. Note that it is not recommended to use a &contrnode; for non-management purposes such as storage or compute.

sect1.title: Deploying &o_img;
sect1.para: &o_img; provides discovery, registration, and delivery services for virtual disk images. An image is needed to start an &vmguest;—it is its pre-installed root-partition. All images you want to use in your cloud to boot &vmguest;s from, are provided by &o_img;.
&o_img; must be deployed onto a &contrnode;. There are a lot of options to configure &o_img;. The most important ones are explained below—for a complete reference refer to .

Choose whether to use &o_objstore; to store the images or to store them in a directory on the &contrnode;. If you have deployed &o_objstore; anyway, it's recommended to use it for &o_img;, too, since it offers higher data security.

This option is only available when having chosen Backing Type File . Specify the directory in which all images uploaded to &o_img; are stored. FIXME: Is the following still possible? If you want to put the images onto a separate partition or volume, you need to mount this partition or volume on the &contrnode; prior to deploying the &o_img; proposal. Specify the mount point of the partition or volume here.
This option is only available when having chosen Backing Type Swift . Sets the name of the container to use for the images in &o_objstore;.
Set this option to true to enable users to upload images to &o_img;. If unset, only the operator will be able to upload images.
Shows debugging output in the log files when set to true.
Enable and configure image caching in this section. By default, image caching is disabled. Learn more about &o_img;'s caching feature at .
Time after which idle database connections will be dropped.
Use syslog logging if set to true.
Enable encrypted communication for &o_img; by choosing HTTPS. Refer to for configuration details.

sect1.title: Deploying &o_blockstore;
sect1.para: &o_blockstore;, the successor of Nova Volume, provides volume block storage. It adds persistent storage to a &vmguest; that will persist until deleted (contrary to ephemeral volumes that will only persist until the &vmguest; is running).

&o_blockstore; can provide volume storage by using a local file, one or more local disks, or the Dell EqualLogic SAN (EQLX). The latter is only available on specific Dell hardware. Using a local file is not recommended for production systems for performance reasons.
The &o_blockstore; service consists of two different roles:

listitem.para: The &o_blockstore; controller provides the scheduler and the API. Installing cinder-controller on a &contrnode; is recommended.

The virtual block storage service. It can be installed on a &contrnode;, but it's recommended to deploy it on a dedicated node supplied with sufficient networking capacity, since it will generate a lot of network traffic. cinder-volume can only be deployed on a single node.

sect1.title: Deploying &o_netw;
sect1.para: &o_netw; provides network connectivity between interface devices managed by other &ostack; services (most likely &o_comp;). The service works by enabling users to create their own networks and then attach interfaces to them.
&o_netw; must be deployed on a &contrnode;. The following attributes can be set to configure &o_netw;:

This option is only available when having chosen Plugin openvswitch . Set the network type to be set up by the plugin: gre (Generic Routing Encapsulation) or flat.
Domain to use for building the host names.
Enable encrypted communication for &o_netw; by choosing HTTPS. Refer to for configuration details.

sect1.title: Deploying &o_comp;
sect1.para: &o_comp; provides key services for managing the &cloud;, sets up the &compnode;s. The &o_comp; service consists of four different roles:

listitem.para: Distributing and scheduling the &vmguest;s is managed by the Nova-multi-controller. It also provides networking and messaging services. Nova-multi-controller needs to be installed on a &contrnode;.

Provides the hypervisors (&kvm;, QEMU, and &xen;) and tools needed to manage the &vmguest;s. Only one hypervisor can be deployed on a single compute node but you can use different hypervisors in your cloud by deploying different hypervisors to different compute nodes. A Nova-multi-compute role needs to be installed on every &compnode;. However, not all hypervisors need to be deployed.

sect1.para: The following attributes can be configured:

listitem.para: Shows debugging output in the log files when set to true.
FIXME (NFS volumes??)

Allows to move &vmguest;s to a different &compnode;. Useful when a &compnode; needs to be shut down or rebooted for maintenance or when the load of the &compnode; is very high. &vmguest;s can be moved while running (Live Migration).

term.guimenu: Virtual RAM to Physical RAM allocation ratio

listitem.para: Set the overcommit ratio for RAM for &vmguest;s on the &compnode;s. A ratio of 1.0 means no overcommitment. Changing this value is not recommended.

term.guimenu: Virtual CPU to Physical CPU allocation ratio

listitem.para: Set the overcommit ratio for CPUs for &vmguest;s on the &compnode;s. A ratio of 1.0 means no overcommitment.

term.guimenu: KVM Options: Enable Kernel Samepage Merging

listitem.para: Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) is a Linux Kernel feature which merges identical memory pages from multiple running processes into one memory region. Enabling it optimizes memory usage on the &compnode;s when using the &kvm; hypervisor at the cost of slightly increasing CPU usage.
Enable encrypted communication for &o_comp; by choosing HTTPS. Refer to for configuration details.

After having started an instance you can display its VNC console in the Nova ‐ via the browser using the noVNC implementation. By default this connection is not encrypted and can potentially be eavesdropped.
Enable encrypted communication for noVNC by choosing HTTPS. Refer to for configuration details.

sect1.title: Deploying the Nova ‐
sect1.para: The last service that needs to be deployed is the Nova ‐. It provides a Web interface for users to start and stop &vmguest;s and for administrators to manage users, groups, roles, etc. Nova ‐ should be installed on a &contrnode;.
The following attributes can be configured:

listitem.para: Enable encrypted communication for Nova ‐ by choosing HTTPS. Refer to for configuration details.

sect1.title: How to Proceed
sect1.para: With a successful deployment of the Nova ‐, the &productname; installation is finished. In order to be able to test your setup by starting an &vmguest; one last step remains to be done—uploading an image to the &o_img; service. Refer to for instructions. Images for &cloud; can be built in SUSE Studio—see this blog post for details: .
Now you can hand over to the cloud administrator to set up users, roles, flavors, etc.— refer to the for details.
